R  egional Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number:  42055 
August 2008 
 
 
 
 
Improving  Price  Collection  of  Non-Household 
Expenditure  Components  and  Updating  Purchasing 
Power  Parity  Estimates  for  Selected  Developing 
Member Countries
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS

  DMC  –  developing member country 
  ERD  –  Economics and Research Department

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Targeting Classification   –  General intervention 
Sector  –  Law, economic management, and public policy 
Subsector  –  Economic management 
Themes  –  Governance, capacity development, inclusive social development

Vice-President  U. Schäfer-Preuss, Knowledge Management and Sustainable

Chief Economist  I. Ali, Economics and Research Department (ERD) 
   
Team leader  C. Palanyandy, Principal Statistician, ERDI  
Team member  E. Capilit, Assistant Economics and Statistics Analyst, ERDI

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) implemented the regional technical assistance 
(RETA)  on  Strengthening  and  Collection  of  Purchasing  Power  Parity  Data  in  Selected 
Developing Member Countries1, which conducted the 2005 International Comparison Program 
for Asia and the Pacific (ICP Asia Pacific) from 2003 to 2007.  The RETA compiled 2005 
purchasing power parity (PPP) data for major macroeconomic variables. It produced regionally 
comparable price levels, expenditure values, and PPP estimates that can inform national policy 
makers, economists, international organizations, and academics about the relative purchasing 
power of citizens of the participating economies. Major aggregates of the ICP such as the final 
consumption  expenditure  generated  robust  price-level  data  for  policy-relevant  expenditure 
categories such as the share of food in household consumption in different economies or the 
share of total food outlays spent on staple products. 2   
 
2.  PPPs also play a crucial role in generating internationally comparable estimates of 
poverty.  Whether the task is to determine an international poverty line (IPL) or to convert a 
given IPL into local currency units, the importance of using an appropriate PPP cannot be over-
emphasized. In fact, quantifying the purchasing power differences across countries and income 
groups is the first and vital step for compiling an IPL ($1-a-day) that is critical for measuring and 
comparing the prevalence of poverty, and for monitoring the effectiveness of poverty reduction 
policies—the first of the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs). 
 
3.   ICP Asia Pacific has become the premier source of information on regional comparisons 
and MDG monitoring. The experience obtained from it demonstrates that good governance, and 
strong commitment and dedicated cooperation of the participating economies are important 
ingredients in achieving the success of the biggest regional statistical undertaking in the area. 
The 2005 ICP Asia Pacific has been hailed as a statistical milestone with the participation of 23 
economies in the region; however, there is much more to do and many challenges remain. The 
proposed RETA intends to address those challenges by building on the momentum of the 
recently concluded 2005 ICP round and capitalizing on the benefits of capacity-building steps 
taken by national statistical offices (NSOs) to ensure sustainability of the ICP framework for 
non-benchmark  years.3  Addressing  these  concerns  is  seen  to  increase  the  leverage  and 
readiness of ADB’s developing member countries (DMCs) in the region for the next round of 
benchmark ICP targeted in 2011.  The RETA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 
1.4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  A continuing challenge for the ICP in the Asia and Pacific region is the need to gain the 
cooperation  of  NSOs  in  providing  data  that  are  not  a  standard  part  of  their  regular  data 
collection exercises. Although the NSOs involved in the 2005 ICP have benefited either directly 
or indirectly from the ICP experience and have come to see the advantage of the ICP structured 
product and service description, data-handling methods, and other procedures that have aided 
in their national work, the priority for most of them is still their national statistics. Therefore,, it 
may be appropriate for the ICP to integrate and align ICP data requests as closely as possible 
with the regular NSO work with prices and national accounts. Such integration could enable

of Purchasing Power Parity Data.  Manila (TA 6088-REG, approved on 19 December, for $1.2 million). 
2    ADB. 2007. Purchasing Power Parities and Real Expenditures, 2005 ICP Asia Pacific. Manila (Tables 30–31). 
3    A non-benchmark year is one when no global ICP is being conducted. 
4   The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 10 July 2008.

2  
more frequent and less expensive ICP activities.  For instance, the Organization for Economic 
Co-operation and Development/Eurostat model uses a 3-year price collection program. For 
them, the additional effort required for price comparison is relatively small. Most of the required 
data are already regularly collected. This is one possibility the RETA proposes to explore. Such 
a strategy would clearly reduce costs for countries, maintain the necessary expertise, and allow 
the  alignment  of  the  technical  capacity-building  effort  with  price  and  national  accounts 
programs, which are already subject to much technical assistance.   
 
5.  The framework for collecting prices for the consumer price index (CPI) in countries is 
geared toward getting a good reading on temporal price movements, i.e., to measure price 
movements over time within a country. Products priced are country-specific, taking into account 
country-specific consumption patterns, habits, etc. However, this framework for collecting prices 
is not much of a guide for spatial price differences. Hence, the ICP product list that was created 
required pricing comparable items of expenditure across national boundaries. In the 2005 ICP, a 
total of 656 products were priced.  Most countries found the surveys very costly in terms of both 
human resource and budgetary requirements because of a significant increase in the workload. 
This poses a challenge on the sustainability of the PPP for non-benchmark years. A balanced 
reduction  in  the  number  of  ICP  products,  combined  with  initiatives  aimed  at  aligning  and 
mainstreaming the ICP activities more closely in routine statistical programs of NSOs, would 
ensure the sustainability of the comparison program during non-benchmark years. It would also 
significantly reduce operational costs and ensure that price inputs for estimating PPPs during 
non-benchmark years will be available. To address the issue, the rich database generated from 
the 2005 ICP will be explored for generating a primary product list.  
 
6.  Harmonizing the ICP and CPI price collection was also emphasized in the country 
reports relating to experiences gained from the 2005 ICP. A largely reduced list would not only 
enable countries to absorb the cost of pricing an additional list of ICP products, but would also 
allow  for  an  uninterrupted  flow  of  the  regular  price  collection  survey.  To  facilitate  such 
integration, the primary product list needs to be matched with the CPI product list to establish 
overlaps.  Products outside the overlap would be kept to a minimum without jeopardizing the 
integrity of the PPP computation. 
 
7.  The 2005 ICP had introduced new approaches in  pricing non-household consumption 
expenditure, especially those relating to investment or gross fixed capital formation, such as 
machinery and equipment; and construction. Construction is a major part of investment, but it is 
also one of the most difficult components of the gross domestic product (GDP) to price. The 
2005 ICP measures relative prices at the level of the construction components such as major 
installed components of construction projects, labor, and equipment. A major benefit of this new 
approach  is  that  it  can  be  used  to  build  in  countries  the  capacity  to  price  construction 
components for potential use in the construction sector. The other major part of investment is 
capital equipment.  This is another problematic area for pricing. During the 2005 ICP, the 
structured  product  description  (SPD)  methodology  was  introduced  for  equipment  (and 
household consumption items). The SPD approach systematically captures price-determining 
characteristics that uniquely define a product. This method allows harmonizing the individual 
country  equipment  lists  used  for  price  surveys.    In  the  Asia  and  Pacific  region,  these 
methodologies are relatively new and should be further refined and fully exploited. Countries 
would be encouraged to adopt these new frameworks in producing national price indicators. 
They can expect to see improvements in their ability to monitor product quality and control for 
variations through time.

3 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The RETA’s intended impact is increased implementation of international standards in 
macro- and micro-economic statistics with emphasis on price statistics.  In particular, the impact 
is greater harmonization of ICP with CPI price collection activities in NSOs through a more 
manageable regional ICP operation. The RETA seeks to institutionalize ICP price collections in 
the NSOs’ regular price surveys to enable updates of PPP estimates for non-benchmark years, 
by generating a core and/or primary product list, which will be a subset of the 2005 ICP product 
list. The RETA would also support the development of NSOs’ expertise in new price collection 
methodologies introduced during the 2005 ICP and encourage them to participate in  enhancing 
these methodologies and subsequently adopting them in producing their own price indices and 
indicators. By the end of the RETA, the following would have been achieved: (i) a primary 
product list for price collection on a regular basis to enable PPP estimation in non-benchmark 
years for participating DMCs; (ii) price data for household products for non-benchmark years 
mainstreamed into the consumer price surveys of NSOs; (iii) implementation of recommended 
methodologies for pricing gross fixed capital formation components; (iv) further development of 
the capacity of NSOs to  collect more reliable price data inputs for PPP computation; and, 
finally, (v) an updated PPP generated for 2009 as the selected non-benchmark year.     
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
9.  To achieve the desired outcome, the RETA will consist of the following activities: (i) 
invite countries to participate in the RETA; (ii) identify items for the primary product list; (iii) 
collect  and  validate  price  data,  and  estimate  the  2009  PPP,  including  mainstreaming  the 
household consumption items into the consumer price collection surveys; (iv) improve statistical 
capacity building; and (v) explore knowledge management systems.. 
 
1.  Inviting Countries to Participate in the RETA 
 
10.  Letters of invitation will be sent to the DMCs that participated in the 2005 ICP  Asia 
Pacific to determine their willingness to participate in the new RETA.  
 
2.  Identifying Items for the Primary/Core Product List  
 
11.  The core product list will be drawn from the product lists used in computing the 2005 
PPPs  for  the  Asia  and  Pacific  region.  Research  will  use  statistical  tools  to  establish  a 
primary/core product list, which should be about one third of the full list of 656 products priced 
during the 2005 ICP Asia Pacific. The subset list, while reduced in number, must remain 
relevant  and  significant  for  the  PPP  computation.    The  possibility  of  including  products 
characteristic of the subregions (subregional baskets) in the Asia and Pacific region would be 
explored, but they will not necessarily be included in the core product list, if doing so would 
dramatically lengthen the list. 
 
3.  Collecting and Validating Price Data and Estimating 2009 PPP  
 
12.  Price data will be collected for the primary product lists for household consumption 
aggregate and construction. Mainstreaming ICP price collection (for household products) into 
the CPI price collection will maximize the use of CPI price information and of the established

4  
organizational structure for collecting price data in the countries.  These activities, in turn, are 
intended to strengthen general management of data compilation and the overall organization of 
price collection activities. Like the benchmark figures, household data will be national average 
prices. Construction, prices will be collected for a single period due to the complexity and costs 
involved in price collection. For governments, pricing information (compensation) would be 
collected from NSOs for a single period.   Meanwhile, given the difficulty of collecting prices for 
equipment as experienced in the 2005 ICP, an alternative methodology for pricing equipment 
will be the subject of research to be undertaken.  For GDP weights, participating countries will 
be requested to provide data as close as possible to 2009. 
 
13.  Since the quality and reliability of PPP estimates depend on the quality of price data 
inputs used in PPP computation, intra-(within) and inter-country validation will be crucial in 
ensuring  product  comparability  and  price  reliability.    The  RETA  will  improve  on  the  data 
validation modules used in the 2005 ICP and develop additional procedures for intra- and inter-
country validation of price data.  Data validation workshops, which proved effective during the 
2005 ICP round, would again be convened for this purpose. 
 
14.  Using  the  new  prices  collected  and  prices  generated  from  alternative  pricing 
methodologies, and updated GDP weights, the 2009 PPP estimates will be generated.  A report 
on the 2009 PPPs will be prepared and circulated.  
 
4.  Building Statistical Capacity  
 
15.  Statistical capacity building will be at the country level and at the Development Indicators 
and Policy Research Division (ERDI) of ADB’s Economics and Research Department. At the 
country level, NSOs gained technical expertise (from the 2005 ICP Asia Pacific) in specifying 
and identifying products, conducting price surveys, validating price data, and understanding the 
rudiments of PPP estimation. The RETA hopes to capitalize and build on this preexisting base 
and further hone the NSOs’ proficiency at conducting ICP price surveys and validating price 
data. Likewise, given the new methodologies adopted during the 2005 ICP, the countries would 
be  encouraged  to  participate  in  their  enhancement  and  to  eventually  adopt  these  new 
frameworks (i.e., the SPD approach) in producing their own price indices and indicators. The 
RETA would also have established the strategies for mainstreaming ICP price collection into 
national statistical programs, which will ensure the availability of consistent and comparable 
price data during non-benchmark years. At ERDI, ADB staff would have developed their skills at 
identifying a core list of products significant in estimating PPP, sharpened skills in validating 
data,  and  gained  knowledge  and  expertise  in  developing  and  implementing  alternative 
approaches to estimating PPPs for non-benchmark years. 
  
5.  Exploring Knowledge Management Systems 
 
16.  Upon successful completion of the RETA, the following would have been achieved: (i) 
participating countries would have provided the price data inputs for computing PPP data for 
2009,  (ii)  country  experiences  would  have  shown  the  facilitating  factors  and  problems  in 
integrating ICP and CPI price data collection efforts, (iii) the methodologies introduced in the 
2005 ICP would have been further refined and more efficiently exploited, and (iv) the 2005 PPP 
would have been updated to 2009 as the first non-benchmark year estimate. 
 
17.  The  GDP  based  on  the  2009  PPP  will  be  published  and  major  sub-aggregates  of 
participating DMCs will be produced.  The publication will be circulated among the NSOs and 
other relevant agencies in the region. To disseminate the RETA output, the results will also be

5 
published on the ADB website under the economic and statistics webpage as well as the 
websites of participating NSOs.  Before the RETA ends, a concluding workshop will be held at 
which participating DMCs will present their results and their future courses of action to ensure 
the sustainability of PPP compilation. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
18.  The total cost of the RETA is estimated at $600,000. This amount includes (i) consulting 
services;  (ii)  training,  seminars,  and  conferences;  (iii)  surveys;  and  (iv)  miscellaneous 
administration and support costs.  The RETA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA 
funding program.  The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2  
 
D.  Implementation Agreements 
 
19.  ADB will be the Executing Agency for the RETA, with national statistical offices or 
agencies in charge of price collection activities as Implementing Agencies. The administration of 
the RETA will be handled by the Economics and Research Department. Confirmation of no-
objection will be obtained from the government of each participating DMC prior to starting RETA 
activities in each such DMC, in coordination with their regional departments.     
 
20.  The RETA will be implemented from September 2008 to August 2010, and will finance 
20  person-months  of  consulting  services  provided  by  2  international  and  18  national 
consultants. ADB will select and engage individual consultants in accordance with its Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). The terms of reference of the 
consultants are in Appendix 3.   
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis for 
Improving  Price  Collection  of  Non-Household  Expenditure  Components  and  Updating 
Purchasing Power Parity Estimates for Selected Developing Member Countries, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE OF CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International  Comparison  Program  Expert  (international,  2  person-months, 
intermittent) 
1.  The  international  consultant  should  be  an  economist  or  statistician  with  extensive 
experience in the area of the international comparison program (ICP) including procedures for 
computing purchasing power parity (PPP).  Preferably, he/she must have a working knowledge 
of  the  statistical  systems  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank’s  developing  member  countries 
(DMCs) participating in this regional technical assistance (RETA). 
 
2.  The specific responsibility of the consultant will include, but will not be limited to, the 
following activities.. 
 
(i)  Assess the state of consumer price statistics in terms of geographic and item 
coverage and their potential usefulness as direct inputs into the ICP.  
 
(ii)  Develop a framework and make recommendations that can maximize the use of 
price data collected for consumer price index (CPI) purposes in computing PPPs 
within the ICP framework.  
 
(iii)  Review the product matching methods used previously in ICP price collection 
and assess whether they are appropriate for price collection in updating the 2005 
ICP.  
 
(iv)  Develop draft pricing lists for discussion with participating countries.  
 
(v)  Assist the countries in integrating the collection of prices of goods and services 
included in the ICP list with the regular collection of data for the CPI.  
 
(vi)  Assist  the  RETA  in  developing  the  construction  product  list  and  alternative 
methodologies for estimating the prices of components of gross fixed capital 
formation. 
 
(vii)  Assist  the  Development  Indicators  and  Policy  Research  Division  (ERDI)  in 
deriving the PPP estimates based on the data collected under the technical 
assistance as well as validating price data and gross domestic product weights. 
 
(viii)  Assist the project officer in conducting technical workshops. 
 
(ix)  Prepare  the  technical  report  on  the  results  of  the  technical  assistance  for 
updating the PPP. 
 
 
B.  Economist/Statistician (national, 18 person-months) 
3.  The national consultant should have a strong background in economics and statistics, 
with extensive experience in the area of the ICP and price statistics. He/she should have 
sufficient and practical knowledge on the price collection systems of the participating DMCs and 
be adept in statistical analysis software and database management

12  Appendix 3           
4.  Under the overall guidance and supervision of the project officer, the national consultant 
will perform the following tasks. 
 
(i)  Provide technical and administrative support to the project officer, Development 
Indicators and Policy Research Division staff, and the international consultant of 
the RETA. 
 
(ii)  Assist  in  preparing  and  organizing  relevant  materials/outputs  for  data 
assessment, research, training, and workshops.  
 
(iii)  Assist  in  organizing  workshops  and  training  for  participating  DMCs,  and  in 
preparing the technical documentation for various meetings that will be organized 
as part of the RETA activities. 
 
(iv)  Assist in preparing the report on updating the PPPs for non-benchmark years. 
 
(v)  Perform other tasks as needed.
